page.title: 14VEGETATION ON ASHWORTH MOOR
page.content: In the north-east of the area{( {ASHWORTH MOOR)}there is a type of moorland vegetation which is typical of much of the higher parts of the { {ROSSENDALE HILLS.} The extent to which this vegetation is 'natural' is difficult to asses because it must to some extent be a response to centuries of grazing by animals (mainly sheep). A sample survey was carried out using quadrant squares placed randomly at approximately 250 metre intervals from just north of the Edenfield road (altitude 950 feet to near the summit of Knowl Moor (altitude 1200 feet). In each square the percentage value for ground cover was estimated for the main species.
